author: Jonathan Walker
title: Nissan investment shows Brexit can work - but what did we offer in return?
text:

We heard a lot about Nissan during the EU referendum, as opponents of Brexit warned that quitting the European Union could deter firms such as the Japanese car giant from investing in the United Kingdom. 
But it wasn’t unusual for politicians to focus on Nissan. 
When they want to show their commitment to the North East, the Sunderland car plant is often their first port of call. 
Former prime minister David Cameron turned up to celebrate the launch of the Nissan Leaf in 2013. 
Nick Clegg arrived, in his role as deputy prime minister, a year later. 
And former Labour leader Ed Miliband also visited in 2014. 
It’s no secret why. The plant is a major employer, with 6,700 staff. Qashqai production at Nissan's Sunderland plant 
And that’s just the tip of the iceberg, because it also supports thousands of jobs in smaller firms which supply goods and services. 
Nissan is a massive success. David Cameron told the House of Commons last year: “The achievements at Nissan are absolutely remarkable. One of the great privileges of my job is being able to go and meet people there and see what they are doing. Read More Nissan secures 7,000 jobs by confirming Qashqai will be built in North East 
“I think that I am right in saying that the north-east of England now produces more cars than the whole of Italy, which is something that I think we can be proud of.” 
But the “remain” campaign was telling the truth when it said that leaving the EU put future investment in the plant at risk. It wasn’t project fear - it was project reality. 
That’s why the announcement that Nissan is to build the new Qashqai and the X-Trail SUV in Sunderland is so important. A worker puts the finishing touches on a Nissan Qashqai 
In fact, the decision to bring the X-Trail SUV to the North East came as a surprise - a very welcome one, of course - even to the Government. The decision is better than expected. 
Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn warned in September that he could decide to build the Qashqai elsewhere unless the Government promised to provide compensation for any tariffs that may be imposed after Brexit. 
He said: “If I need to make an investment in the next few months and I can’t wait until the end of Brexit , then I have to make a deal with the UK government. If there are tax barriers being established on cars, you have to have a commitment for carmakers who export to Europe that there is some kind of compensation.” 
There may have been an element of brinkmanship in this, as some industry experts have questioned whether Nissan had another plant capable of building the vehicle without massive investment. The new Nissan Qashqai is produced on the assembly line at the Nissan Sunderland plant 
But the Government took the threat seriously. Prime minister Theresa May held talks with Mr Ghosn in Number 10. 
Insiders say the deal was done, however, when business secretary Greg Clark travelled to Japan to meet Nissan bosses. 
What we don’t know is what exactly that deal involves. 
Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson raised this question in the House of Commons this week. He said it appeared - though we can’t know for sure - that Brexit had forced the Government to subsidise industries, in order to convince overseas firms to invest in the UK. 
For the Government, however, the lesson is clear. It shows that the UK can make a success of Brexit. 
Mrs May hammered home the message in a statement welcoming the decision, saying: “This vote of confidence shows Britain is open for business and that we remain an outward-looking, world-leading nation.” 
The prime minister, and Greg Clark, never wanted the UK to quit the EU. They were both remainers. 
But their task now is to ensure that we continue to have a strong economy as we leave. 
The Nissan announcement suggests that the goal is achievable. And of course, it’s fantastic news for the North East. 
But it does also illustrate the danger that Brexit poses to our economy. Because while credit must go to Mr Clark for securing the investment, it would have been in far less doubt in the first place if we were staying in the EU.
